From Wiktionary, the free dictionary

English

[edit]

Etymology

[edit]

From justify +‎ -er.

Noun

[edit]

justifier (plural justifiers)

  1. (chiefly philosophy) One who, or that which, justifies some belief or action.
  2. One who pardons and absolves from guilt and punishment.
    • 1867, The Evangelical Repository and United Presbyterian Review, page 483:
      God, essentially considered, in the person of the Father, is especially the justifier, in respect of judiciary power and authority.
  3. (computing, typography) A machine, program or algorithm that justifies text by aligning it.
    • 1955, Book Production, volumes 61-62, page 43:
      When the operator starts typing the third line, the justifier goes to work on the second.

Derived terms

[edit]
  • self-justifier

Translations

[edit]
one who justifies
  • Latin: iustificator m
  • Swedish: rättfärdiggörare c

French

[edit]

Etymology

[edit]

Inherited from Old French justifier, borrowed from Late Latin iūstificāre.

Pronunciation

[edit]
  • IPA(key): /ʒys.ti.fje/
  • Audio (France (Vosges)):(file)
  • Audio (France (Lyon)):(file)
  • Audio (France (Somain)):(file)

Verb

[edit]

justifier

  1. to justify

1 The French gerund is usable only with the preposition en.
2 In less formal writing or speech, these tenses may be found to have been replaced in the following way:
past historic → present perfect
past anterior → pluperfect
imperfect subjunctive → present subjunctive
pluperfect subjunctive → past subjunctive

(Christopher Kendris [1995], Master the Basics: French, pp. 77, 78, 79, 81).

Derived terms

[edit]
  • la fin justifie les moyens

Related terms

[edit]
  • justification
  • juste

[edit]
  • → Romanian: justifica

Further reading

[edit]
  • “justifier”, in Trésor de la langue française informatisé [Digitized Treasury of the French Language], 2012.

Old French

[edit]

Etymology

[edit]

Borrowed from Latin iūstificāre.

Verb

[edit]

justifier

  1. to show to be innocent
    • 12th century, Cambridge Psalter
      E ne vienges pas a jugier od tun serf, ker n'en iert pas justifiiez el tun esguardemenz
      (please add an English translation of this quotation)

Conjugation

[edit]

This verb conjugates as a first-group verb ending in -er. Old French conjugation varies significantly by date and by region. The following conjugation should be treated as a guide.

    Conjugation of justifier (see also Appendix:Old French verbs)
simple compound
infinitive justifier avoir justifïé
gerund en justifiant gerund of avoir + past participle
present participle justifiant
past participle justifïé
person singular plural
first second third first second third
indicative jo tu il nos vos il
simple
tenses 		present justifi justifïes justifïe justifions justifïez justifïent
imperfect justifioie, justifïeie, justifioe, justifïeve justifioies, justifïeies, justifioes, justifïeves justifioit, justifïeit, justifiot, justifïeve justifiiiens, justifiiens justifiiiez, justifiiez justifioient, justifïeient, justifioent, justifïevent
preterite justifiai justifias justifia justifiames justifiastes justifïerent
future justifïerai justifïeras justifïera justifïerons justifïeroiz, justifïereiz, justifïerez justifïeront
conditional justifïeroie, justifïereie justifïeroies, justifïereies justifïeroit, justifïereit justifïeriiens, justifïeriens justifïeriiez, justifïeriez justifïeroient, justifïereient

Descendants

[edit]
  • French: justifier
    • → Romanian: justifica
  • → Middle English: justifien
    • English: justify
    • Scots: justifee
